quiz.title: Graphing Horizontal and Vertical Lines
quiz.subtitle: Unit 4.4: Special Cases of Linear Equations
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Horizontal Lines, Vertical Lines, and Their Equations

questions.question: What is the equation of a horizontal line passing through $(3, -2)$?
questions.explanation: Horizontal lines have constant y-values. Since it passes through $(3, -2)$, all points have $y = -2$, so equation is $y = -2$.

questions.question: Which equation represents a vertical line?
questions.explanation: Vertical lines have constant x-values. Only $x = 5$ has x constant (all points have x = 5).

questions.question: What is the slope of the line $x = -4$?
questions.explanation: Vertical lines have undefined slope because $\Delta x = 0$, making slope $m = \frac{\Delta y}{0}$ undefined.

questions.question: Which graph shows the line $y = 3$?
questions.explanation: $y = 3$ is a horizontal line where y is always 3, regardless of x.

questions.question: A line passes through points $(5, 1)$, $(5, -2)$, and $(5, 4)$. What is its equation?
questions.explanation: All points have $x = 5$ (constant), so it's a vertical line with equation $x = 5$.

questions.question: What is the y-intercept of the line $x = 7$?
questions.explanation: Vertical line $x = 7$ never crosses the y-axis (where $x = 0$), so it has no y-intercept.

questions.question: Which statement is true about $y = -1$?
options: It's a horizontal line with slope 0
It's a vertical line with undefined slope

questions.question: How would you graph the line $x = -2$?
questions.explanation: $x = -2$ means x is always $-2$. This is a vertical line passing through all points where $x = -2$, such as $(-2, 0)$, $(-2, 1)$, $(-2, -1)$, etc.

questions.question: Which line is parallel to the x-axis?
questions.explanation: Lines parallel to the x-axis are horizontal lines with equations $y = constant$.

questions.question: A line has points $( -3, 2)$, $(0, 2)$, and $(4, 2)$. What describes it?
questions.explanation: All points have $y = 2$ (constant y), so it's a horizontal line $y = 2$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of special lines! You clearly distinguish horizontal/vertical cases and their properties.
scoreMessages.70: Strong grasp of concepts! Review: 1) No y-intercept for vertical lines, 2) Slope = 0 vs undefined.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Focus on: Horizontal = constant y, slope 0. Vertical = constant x, undefined slope.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: $y = \text{number}$ gives horizontal line. $x = \text{number}$ gives vertical line. Practice identifying from points.
